column1: What is now Franklin Square was near the center of the Hempstead Plains
column2: and used as grazing land
column4: by the first white settlers. The southern portion included oak and dogwood forests.

column2: Robert Fordham and John Carman made a treaty with members of the Massapequak
column4: Matinecock and Rockaway tribes to buy roughly 100 square miles upon which they intended to start a new settlement. They purchased this tract
column5: including much of what are now the towns of Hempstead and North Hempstead. The source of the name "Franklin Square" is unclear. It has been speculated that the name honors Benjamin Franklin
column6: but he had no historical connection to the area. It has been suggested that it was named for some now-forgotten local settler or notable.

column2: George Washington passed through the town while touring Long Island. He wrote in his diary that the area was "entirely treeless except for a few scraggly fruit trees." Walt Whitman spent three months in the spring of 1840 as the schoolmaster of the Trimming Square school district
column3: in the area where Franklin Square
column4: Garden City South and West Hempstead intersect.

column2: one Louis Schroerer built a hotel near a tollgate (by what is now Arden Boulevard) of the Hempstead-Jamaica Turnpike (toll road). The hotel attracted an increasing number of visitors and immigrants (the latter often German) from New York City to the formerly rural hamlet. Population grew steadily until the sudden intensified surge of suburbanization into post-World War II Long Island reached the village. By 1952
column4: replaced by newly built houses full of emigrants from nearby New York City.

column1: Franklin Square was the home of the Franklin National Bank
column2: once the nation's 20th largest bank. Under the leadership of Arthur T. Roth
column3: the Franklin National Bank introduced many banking innovations
column4: such as the bank credit card
column7: and a no-smoking policy on banking floors (1958).

column3: the Franklin National Bank was declared insolvent due to mismanagement and fraud
column4: involving losses in foreign currency speculation and poor loan policies. This caused massive losses for its stockholders
column5: resulted in jail and disgrace for its management; Italian financier and CEO Michele Sindona was poisoned in his cell in 1986
column6: while serving a life-sentence for his part in this affair. It was at the time the largest bank failure in the history of the country
column7: and forced US banking policymakers to reexamine and reassess regulation of international banking.

column1: The building was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 2015.

column1: Franklin Square is served by three school districts 13

The Valley Stream Union Free School District 13 covers the four public elementary schools in Franklin Square (Willow Road School is located in Franklin Square under Valley Stream District) and two public high schools (North Valley Stream H.S. is located in Franklin Square under Valley Stream District). The Franklin Square Union Free District 17 covers Washington Street School
column5: and Polk Street School. District 16 (Elmont School district)
column7: with most students attending Covert Ave School and Sewanhaka High School.

column1: Franklin Square has a volunteer fire department and is served by the Nassau County Police Department's Fifth Precinct.Franklin Square residents are served by two public libraries
column2: the Elmont Public Library and the Franklin Square Public Library. Sanitation and recycling services are provided by Town of Hempstead District 6. The Town of Hempstead department of Parks and Recreation operates and maintains Rath Park
column8: and a playground. There is a snack commissary and recreational equipment rental facility that operate during the summer
